she during the question session please
use the microphones in the aisles and
with that let us welcome our speaker hey
y'all are you doing this morning good
I appreciate you braving the heat and
maybe hangovers as well depending on how
late you stayed out last night to come
for this talk I'm gonna talk about on
trust and then we're gonna go through
some of the experiences that I've had
throughout my career leading up to the
Equifax situation when to start off I
want to talk about a day that I will not
ever forget and that day was September
7th 2017 started off like any other
normal day but it wasn't long after I
got into the office that morning that I
get a phone call coming from my CEO and
immediately starts grilling me on a
variety of things
hey 150 million records compromised
what's the data sensitivity do we have
any or connection what are the risks
that we have it was a it was a pretty
trying time and as a Cecil you never
really want to get that phone call to
begin with right
and then that led to the next discussion
which was board members asking the same
type of types of questions the team you
know getting into a frenzy and and you
know running all over the place to try
to get as many answers as they can to
the situation so the net of it was it
was it was a very chaotic and crazy time
September 7th 2017 what's really crazy
about it though is that I was not at
Equifax at this time I was at that
company with the big orange sign the
mecca for do-it-yourselfers I was at
Home Depot and despite this despite the
fact that we had had our own breach in
2015 which I was in the middle of
driving the transformation for the
Equifax breach caused us a lot of pain
why because Equifax is one of our
customers so from a customer perspective
my level of trust in that organization
was meaningfully impacted as was for all
of the other employees boards of
directors and so forth throughout the
organization but it wasn't just that it
wasn't just their customer aspect
personally I was a victim myself so my
information was compromised during that
breach but more importantly to me was
the fact that my daughter who had not
too long before that had just received
her first little Social Security number
and I you know it's pretty cool little
time to see this little thing and you
think oh she's like a real person now
and one of the first things I thought
was my gosh this breach is gonna impact
this and her credentials or her
information is already compromised so it
was it was truly impactful and my level
of trust in the organization wasn't was
meaningfully impacted as a result of
that today I'm sure that many of you in
this room have had the have had similar
stories and had similar impacts as I did
but the impacts weren't just weren't
just as it relates to the personal and
to the customer Equifax was meaningfully
impacted as well so right out of the
gate you have a 40% loss in your market
cap you have the CEO the CSO the CTO all
gone from the organization you make an
incremental investment of one and a
quarter billion dollars it's a lot of
money to be able to reinvest in the
technology and security of the
organization and then you have all of
the scrutiny and so we dealt with a
whole host of investigations as a result
of the breach itself one such
investigation led me earlier this year
myself my CEO was in February led us to
Washington DC to the Dirksen building up
there and it was for congressional
testimony for the Senate permanent
Subcommittee on investigations and when
I'm in this meeting you know the you
sitting there
at the at the desk and you've got all
these cameras in front of you and the
reporters and stuff and you look up and
they the way they set these things up is
pretty intimidating so although you know
the Senators are sitting above you
looking down but right out of the gate
for first question I get is how many
certificates were expired in 2017
all right so they're looking ended up
into the past and trying to piece that
together the next question I get is what
have you done to improve your patching
processes since we believe patching was
a critical weakness for your
organization
and then another one would be you know
if you had an outstanding asset
inventory would you have been able to
stop this breach from occurring right so
going into the speculative piece now
these questions are all meaningful and I
think they're all fine and quite frankly
in my role I've I get these questions
from the media from the regulators from
Shooter our insurance underwriters from
customers and so forth so these aren't
bad questions and they're fairly common
the I think the key thing though is are
they the right questions does it does it
really matter when you talk about these
specific controls does it really get to
the heart of what's really going on
within our industry as a whole and to
answer that I believe that I figured
this out far earlier in my career it
wasn't learning this at Equifax I didn't
learn it at Home Depot it actually goes
back to my first job out of outside
after I finished college and it was it
was at NASA and so in 2003 2003 I'm at
NASA and we have what I believe to be
the greatest crisis I've ever faced
within an organization and it wasn't a
breach more than a breach it was the
2003 shuttle Columbia disaster where we
lost seven outstanding individuals by
virtue of that of that event now in the
wake of that event they put together an
investigation board and they went
through all of the different causes and
and identified all the different
weaknesses within there within the the
situation to be able to identify the
root cause and so the
the initial outcome that's okay look you
you're getting ready to they're getting
ready to launch as you're going through
that process you have a piece of foam
insulation falls off the external tank
hits the left wing damaging it and then
later on upon reentry because of that
damaged wing you get a excess heat which
then cascades throughout the shuttle and
disintegrates upon reentry
it was terrible and so this is all
documented in that report but there is
one very very important conclusion that
they make in that report that I think is
extraordinarily relevant to all of us
here today and what they said I think if
there's anything you take away from this
talk like just remember this what they
said was at NASA an accident was
inevitable so think about that for a
minute
it was inevitable didn't matter if it
was the Columbia or was going to be the
Atlantis for the next launch didn't
matter if it was because of foam
insulation or because of some propulsion
issue an accident was inevitable why was
it inevitable well they said it directly
in their organizational structure and
decision processes were such that it was
going to happen something bad was going
to happen and what does that speak to
that speaks to the culture of the
organization does it speak to the
specific controls it speaks to the
culture and I think that's a critical
piece as we look at the breaches and we
look at the landscape that we're seeing
today if we focus just on the individual
controls that failed I think we're
missing the bigger picture so so a few
weeks or a few months ago I was I was
talking to a CEO of a major financial
institution you guys Jemile you know I'm
not a technical guy so how how will I
know if I have an effective security
organization and I think it's a great
question honestly and I think it's one
of those one of these things that as a
security leader and many of us have to
deal with consistently is trying to sort
of bridge that divide between the
technical aspects and communicating it
to a non-technical audience so what I
told him was there's five things I think
that really matter to be able to help
too
to identify whether you're going to have
a successful security program or not the
first one is is your head of security or
si so are they positioned in the
organization such that they have the
ability to influence the entire
enterprise the reason this is important
because security is everybody's
responsibility if it's just the security
team that's doing security than you're
bound to fail and you need that you need
that level of authority to be able to
push down throughout the entire
enterprise the second one is do does the
head of security have regular
interaction and communications with the
board of directors now this is essential
because you need to be able to manage up
you need to be able to communicate what
those key risks are otherwise they're
going to get buried and they're not
going to be addressed to the degree that
they should the third one is about
incentives and there's a lot of
organizations out there that's sort of
check the box as it relates to to
security it you either you have nothing
or some organizations will have sort of
part of the annual review process you'll
have a little blurb in there about
security doesn't really tie into in any
kind of meaningful economic incentives
the organization's I think they're doing
this really well are the ones that have
taken security and aligned it
economically from a performance
standpoint just like almost all
organizations do as it relates to
top-line growth or bottom line growth or
your margins or your EBIT ah these
things are essential and they're
critical and so if you tie that economic
impact back in to the performance of
your security program it puts you in a
far better place the next one is is
crisis management are you doing
consistent crisis management exercises
with the executive leadership team and
the board of directors if you're not if
you're not what it tells me is that you
don't think a breach is ever going to
happen right it's the same reason that I
put on a seatbelt every single time I
get into a car it's because I know it's
possible that I'm gonna get an accident
and I want to do at least the minimum
amount to ensure that I'm protecting
myself
if the organizations aren't testing
these things then they fundamentally
don't believe it's going to happen to
them and as we know it can happen to
anyone at any time and the final one is
is ties back to risk management
have you has your organization ever
halted or delayed a critical enterprise
initiative because of security or
privacy this is a critical one because
what it speaks to is the fact that if
you have done this you have the right
governance processes in place to be able
to to be able to identify these risks
and escalate them and it means that your
management the CEO the leadership team
whomever has the conviction to actually
do something about it they have the
conviction to to not take advantage of
an immediate opportunity that's you know
gonna give you maybe an X an incremental
dollar of revenue and instead do the
right thing and focus on the risk to the
organization so I think these are all
absolutely critical pieces now think
about your organization's and tell me
whether you check the box on all five of
those things it's likely that you're
it's likely that you don't because
that's just a state of our environment
today but if you do my argument is even
with a mediocre security team if you
have all five of those things checked
you have a far better chance of success
you can have the best security team ever
but if you don't have those five things
on top of you in place then the
likelihood that you're going to be
successful as a team is pretty darn low
no matter how good you are because
you're not gonna have the ability to be
able to drive change now if you look at
the studies today most studies will say
one of the top three things that any
organization that any Board of Directors
or CEO cares about is gonna be
cybersecurity
it's crazy I mean with all the
geopolitical risks with the competitive
challenges that organizations have with
the labor labor issues cyber security
consistently reaches the one of the top
three things so everyone says that it's
really important right but what really
matters to me is what what are you gonna
do about it it's easy to talk it's easy
to say a cyber key to me up and I have
privacy keeps me up at night but but
actually doing something about it
putting some of these pieces in place
takes effort and as a result what we're
what we're seeing is a lot of people
talking about things but not actually
doing them and so there's this thing
called Sadie
that we've implemented at our company
and it comes from our CEO when he when
he started we start about the same time
after the breach and he's like look say
do is absolutely essential we can talk
all we want but if we say something
we've got to deliver on it and it's that
level of action that I think drives the
the meaningful level of progress that
we've seen and I think if more companies
chose to do that we wouldn't be in the
situation in many cases that we are that
we are to that now it's equally
important to note that the environment
is just getting more and more
challenging right every organization is
critically tied into technology and
they're truly relying on technology and
as we all know you know technology
underpins virtually everything within
organizations nowadays and technology is
inherently insecure I mean you can have
something that's that has zero
weaknesses today and I guarantee you
tomorrow it will have something right a
couple that with the reliance on data
that we have and you have a perfect
storm where you've got this reliance on
technology or you have all these massive
amounts of data being created and so we
become infinitely attractive targets all
of us to the bad guys and then you marry
up a new dynamic privacy something that
consumers in general I think for the
longest time have been pretty apathetic
about are now starting to actually care
and as a result you have regulations and
regulators coming in to be able to drive
that as well so it's only going to
continue to get harder for us to be
successful now let me tell you a story
of for me that was extraordinarily
difficult I was at Los Alamos National
Laboratories and I was the CEO there
several years back and and for those of
you don't know it's a it's a nuclear
weapons laboratory and so obviously our
risk tolerance is extraordinarily low
then you face some of the most advanced
threats there are that are out there and
one day one day we got hit and the
adversary penetrated our perimeter and
so they got in now fortunately for us we
were able to watch them as they came in
and we were able to to
to do some meaningful analysis and and
for those of you don't know in
organisations like this often times you
don't want to just kick them out you
want to monitor them and try to learn
from them to try to understand sources
and stuff like that and so we do and we
after analysis we identify that there
was multiple teams coming after us you
did they were running different shifts
we isolated the the origin of those
attacks and who the threat actors were
and eventually they got far enough into
the organization that we said okay now
we're going to too much risk we're gonna
we're gonna kick these guys out so we
did that and you know wipe their hands
of it and that was a good news story the
next morning though I get a phone call
from a peer of mine at a different
laboratory and he says Jamil can you
like we've been we've been popped can
you please send some of your cyber folks
over here to help us help us out with
the situation and of course I'm like
sure great so we send them over there
and what what ended up happening is that
it was so bad they ended up having to
pull the plug from the entire internet
for the entire laboratory for two full
weeks it was that bad the interesting
thing though is that when we went
through and did the analysis what turns
out happened is that both organizations
mine as well as his or both attacked at
the exact same time exact same time and
when we stopped the attacker on our side
they diverted all those resources and
essentially amplified that attack on
this other organization now this is the
free here this thing about we're this
thing about outrunning the bear right
you guys have probably all heard this
you see a bear in the woods you don't
have to outrun it as long as you outrun
your friend they'll get eaten you're
good to go
all right yes a great graphical image in
your mind so so we've heard this and
this was the first time in my career
that I had actually seen direct evidence
supporting this right we after this
occurred I thought geez not only not
only did we succeed here because we
stopped these guys we actually excelled
because they got hit even harder and so
that makes this even better and this was
a huge mistake on my part
this is a big mistake because I looked
at the certain the set of outcomes and a
certain set of data points and I
concluded
I concluded one thing but what I didn't
realize at the time was that neither one
of us won right I didn't win I wasn't
successful because they got hit and as a
result of that we both ended up losing
this fight and this is why I think it's
so critical that we all work together to
be able to raise the bar for
organizations like if you look at things
like privacy today you have one or two
organizations that maybe weren't doing
the right thing and as a result of the
addition result of those of those
weaknesses the entire industry
anyone who's related any organization
tied in to privacy has been lumped in to
that same bucket whether or not they
were doing good or not the same thing
applies to security I can't think of
anything worse than if one of my direct
competitors was compromised which is why
we work so hard to partner with them so
that we're making sure we're all we're
all raising the bar to the best degree
possible let's be honest does it provide
any benefit to anybody if we have
breaches like Marriott or the Capital
One or anything like that it doesn't
help anybody and so we tend to be in
this industry we tend to try to focus on
all the bad and you know point the
finger and say oh well they should have
had this control in place of that
control place what we should be doing is
working more closely with each other
to be able to help raise that bar for
everybody because if we can do that when
we see that bear it's not gonna be about
us trying to outrun the person next to
us because the reality is if that person
gets eaten that's next to you you're the
next target for that bear but if we work
together we have an a fighting chance to
be able to avoid any meaningful impact
negatively for all parties involved and
with that I'm gonna I want to close on I
think what the most important part is
Trust starts and ends with you I have
worked in a lot of places and I've
worked with a lot of individuals there
are we can we can operate in such a way
that we focus more we're like a
Pollyanna right everything's fine it'll
all work out we can be you know the boy
who cried wolf and say you know escalate
everything possible until it all becomes
noise and leadership doesn't even listen
to us anymore because of all the
security issues we sit that's ten things
sometimes honestly because there's a lot
of vulnerabilities out there
so we can take that approach or what we
can do is we can say look I even though
I maybe don't have control over the
Board of Directors or how exactly where
or where I report within my organization
what we can do is we can look inside
ourselves and we can say do I embody the
right attributes am I truly focused in
them I am I embodying the attributes of
the culture that I want to build and do
that day in and day out I think if we
all take this position if we can work
together on this but on these two
challenges that we all face let's be
honest they're all the same kind of
challenges and then we we push for the
kind of culture and we start with
ourselves we fight for tooth and nail
day in and day out make that incremental
level of progress and then we partner
together but I think we have a
meaningful shot at being able to turn
the tide that we've been facing today
and if we do that not only do I think
that we will be successful but I think
all of us collectively have an
opportunity to excel that's my talk I
appreciate the time if there is if there
are any questions you guys have I want
to offer the opportunity for my team to
work directly with yours in this
partnership fashion so please reach out
via LinkedIn or send me an email or
whatever and we can work together as I
think we can turn the tide as a
